review_blob: Bottle. Moderate frothy head over a dark ruby body. Nose is lightly malty, slightly metallic. Palate is medium bodied, caramel and roasted malt. Finish is slightly chocolatey. A solid brew.

Deep dark brown with creamy lacing. Nose is pretty quiet, just a little roasted malt. Palate is creamy, with black malt and hot chili pepper. Finish is chillis, maybe slightly smoky. Good beer, but not complex
Nose is mellow and rounded, with some malty notes, and quite sweet & fruity. Palate is mid bodied, malty, moderately bitter. A decent drop

Bottle from the Good Spirits Co Wine & Beer. Pours a clear reddish amber with s big frothy short- lived head. Nose is a mix of tart, sour red fruits, plus a vanilla oakiness. Palate is light bodied, sweet-sour with s load of raspberry fruitiness. The finish is sherbet like. Very good
beer_name: Mikkeller Acid Trip BA Red Wine

review_blob: Bomber from the Good Spirits Co Wine & Beer. Pours a clear gold (why fine it? Unnecessary, IMHO) with a light lacy head. Aroma is wonderful, full on herbal, funky hops, rsinous and stinky, just the way I love it. Palate is Rich, full on, extremely bitter,but balanced by ripe fruit and a touch of malt. Finish is rather lighter, but with excellent bitterness

Bottle from the Good Spirits Co Wine & Beer. Its very dark for an IPA, more like a heavy in fact. Nose is not expressive, just a bit of malt. Palate is excellent: full on malt, yeast, salty hops, great texture. Finish aint much. Overall, a decent brew.

A can from the Good Spirits Co Wine & Beer, drunk on the train.

The nose is light a bit old fashioned, and slightly dusty. 

Its very light bodied. Very creamy carbonation. Green right enough; sappy. Bitter in the finish, and refreshing.

Good stuff, although not really what I was looking for this evening.

Can from the Good Spirits Co Wine & Beer. Pours a cloudy light gold with a big creamy head. Nose is super funky, downright barnyard in fact. Palate is light, tangy, refreshing. Bitter, but fruity too. The orange notes are not apparent until the finish, which is light, with a creamy texture. I enjoyed this more than the 2015 release.

Can from the Good Spirits Co Wine & Beer. Pours a slightly cloudy gold, with a big frothy short- lived head. Nose is slightly dank, musty, just the kind of funky hops I love. There is malt in there too. Palate is initially rich, malty, with fruity hops, but seems to become a bit watery in the finish. Aftertaste is long and elegantly bitter.
Im not terribly keen on this kind of sour usually, but the clear cut cucumber flavours in this one really worked for me. Tart, green, fresh, delicious

Bottle from the Good Spirits Co Wine & Beer. It pours thick black and oily, with a small head gradually building up. Aroma is outstanding - the very best mocha coffee, with some treacle toffee too.Palate is very full and rich: treacle, coffee, malt, bitter-sweet. Texture is amazing - silky, thick, creamy. Wonderful stuff

From the Good Spirits Co. Wine & Beer. Very pale in appearance, with just a lacing of foam. Nose is light, clean, slightly biscuity malt. Palate is excellent: hoppy, light, refreshing. The carbonation is a little too much for my taste, but thats a very minor quibble.

Bottle from the Good Spirits Co. Wine & Beer. Pours a deep gold with a thin white head. Aromas of bitter hops - slightly metallic - and a little sweet malt. Palate is immense: a huge hit of bitter hops, thick sweet caramel malt, resinous hops, and a very long salty-bitter finish. My kinda beer.

Bottle from the Good Spirits Co. Wine & Beer. Pours a pale gold with a light froth. Nose is light for a DIPA, and quite clean. Nothing funky here. Yellow fruit notes. The palate is light, well balanced, very fruity, quite tropical. I do not like the carbonation or the finish - it seems a bit raw, and there is a wee off note in the finish. Slightly disappointing.

8Hand pulled pint at the Bon Accord. The pump clip claimed either 65 or 85 IBUs - I dont believe that. A pale gold pint with just a light frothy head. Nose is fairly quiet, but promising - bitter, fruity, fresh. The palate is balanced and lightly bitter (definitely not 85 IBUs), with light malty notes. A very good session pint. Maybe the clip said 35 IBUs?

Can from the Good Spirits Co Wine & Beer. Pale slightly cloudy gold with a light froth. Nose is powerful stinky hops, and kinda dank dungeons too. Palate is bitter hops, yellow fruity-sweet, a touch of noticeable alcohol, and subtle sweet malt. Finish is super refreshing. Absolutely ace.

Bottle from the Good Spirits Co. Wine & Beer. Pours clear gold with a big frothy head. Nose is clean, fresh, and light. Palate is fruity (citrus, tending to oranges) and light, with a fair dose of hoppy bitterness. Very good, but rather lighter than I was expecting it to be.

Can from the Good Spirits Co. Wine & Beer. Very pale yellow with generous foam. Light nose, fruity (orange / jaffa cake). Palate is light, bitter, refreshing. Citrus sweetness balances it out. Carbonation is a little too much for my taste. Good stuff

Bottle from the Good Spirits Co. Wine & Beer. This particular bottle has zero carbonation - it is completely flat. In my opinion, that means that the beer is faulty. That aside, there are some good flavours here. Nose has excellent caramel maltiness, palate is sweet and fruity. Its rather darker than one might expect in an IPA, but I suppose all that malt has to go somewhere. An honourable failure.

Bottle from the Good Spirits Co. Wine & Beer. Cloudy gold with a persistent skim of froth. Nose has the requisite sharpness of a saison, along with interesting sweet fruity hop notes. palate is quite thick/rich for a saison, with sweet malt, bitter hops, and a sour-sharp note from the saison yeast. Jolly Good stuff!
beer_name: Wiper and True Saison Cobbles & Clouds

review_blob: Bottle from the Good Spirits Co Wine & Beer. Hazy amber with light froth. Nose is fresh, fruity hops (citric/tropical). Palate is light, refreshing, fruity, into a light bitter finish. This would be a great session beer if it were 3.5%
Pint at the Laurieston. Not much head, but a good dark amber colour. Nose is hoppy, fruity, intense. Maybe a little bit tobacco? Palate is malty sweet AND bitter, great balance.

Can from the Good Spirits Co Wine & Beer. Dense black, with creamy lacing. Nose smoky, sweet, creamy, metallic. Palate is rich, very full, bitter sweet (roasty malt) with a salty swet finish. Treacly. Warm too, without being overtly boozy. Ace.

Bottle from the Good Spirits Co. Wine & Beer. Slightly cloudy gold, light frothy rim. Nose is fruity hops, sweet caramel. Palate is medium bodied, bitter sweet, bright yellow fruits, slightly rasping carbonation. Long juicy bitter hop finish. My kinda beer, with only the carbonation keeping it from being perfect.
beer_name: Howling Hops IPA West Coast Special No. 2

review_blob: Bottle from the Good Spirits Wine & Beer. Pours black, with a very retentive thick creamy head. Nose is rather disappointing, metallic, not encouraging. Palate is full, thick, complex. Creamy, lots of chilli spice, some chocolate notes. Finish is burnt, malty, chilli heat and a wee bit of caramel. Good effort.
Pint at the Bon Accord. Very very pale, but the nose is reassuringly aromatic - fruity and sharp. Palate is super-bitter, light, refreshing.Very clean finish.
A can, on the train. Medium bodied, refreshing, with some fruity hop flavours and loads of bitterness. If only it were a bit weaker it would make a perfect session beer.

33cl bottle at home. Pours a giant white frothy head over slightly hazy gold. Nose is Belgian, slightly leathery, a little woody - subtle and very well balanced. Palate is just off dry: great balance between sweet candy sugar, malt, and bitter hops. The carbonation is a bit mad on this bottle, hence the lower mark for palate.

330ml bottle from the Good Spirits Co Wine & Beer. Black, with minimal head. Nose is a fascinating mix of Brett and roasted malt. Perhaps a little creamy too. Palate is full bodied, sour, salty. Dry finish, with a burnt edge to it. Good stuff.

Slightly hazy reddish amber with light froth. Nose is resinous, bitter, plus salty caramel. Palate is green, hoppy, fruity, tasty. As with quite a few Tempest beers, I dont like the carbonation - its a bit scratchy. Great flavours though.
beer_name: Tempest A Face With No Name

review_blob:
Oh my goodness, what a fantastic beer.

A 330ml bottle. Pours black, with a deep brown frothy/creamy head, fairly persistent. Nose is beautiful, fresh mocha coffee plus creamy nutty chocolate. Palate is sweet coffee, treacle toffee, bitter hoppy finish. Then tobacco, some green tangy hop notes. Great finish & aftertaste.

I want to do a head to head, but for now Im going to put my neck out and say that this stuff is better than Founders KBS.

Awesome beer.
Its not often a beer makes me laugh out loud, but this one did. Its pure fizzy grapefruit on the nose and a big hit of the same on the palate. But its also a bitter hoppy refreshing brew. Perfect.

Tasted 2015-11-05. If you are going to buy this (assuming its still available) then buy 2. Or 3. When I tasted it I struggled to find much brett. It was a very fine IPA - more bitter than aromatic. But Id love to re-taste it in 6 months and see where the brett has developed.

Bomber from The Good Spirits Co. Wine & Beer. Pours a deep gold witha slight haze. the White head doesnt last long. Nose is pretty muted to start, becoming orangey and a little funky as it warms up.

Palate is initially very bitter seville orange marmalade, with a superb long bitter finish. Over time the bitterness evolves to walnut skins. I dont really taste any malt, but the balance is superb, so it must be in there in a supporting role.

Overall a great beer. Tis a pity about the strength; Id love to have this sort of beer for sessioning.
Can. Pitch black with a short lived tan head. Nose is generic imperial stout, no cherries. Palate is sweet, creamy, bitter chocolate. Very good, but I dont really taste the cherries
beer_name: Beavertown Heavy Water (Sour Cherry and Sea Salt)

review_blob: 330ml stubbie from the Good Spirits Co. Wine & Beer. Appearance is palce cloudy gold with a big, fast-fading, foamy head. Nose is extremely fruity - tangerine - and aromatic. Palate is awfully light for an APA, but good bitterness and more of the citrus fruit. Short finish. Overall good, but not malty enough to justify the name.
beer_name: Left Handed Giant Duet - Southern Cross & Mosaic

review_blob: Can. Cloudy gold with a frothy white head. Nose is funky, sweaty hops, a little metallic, some tropical fruit. Palate is sweet tropical fruit, quite light bodied, then an incredibly long bitter finish. Superb.

Bottle. A bit of a gusher. Nose is great, with funky brett notes, oak, citric hops. Palate is sweet - quite honeyed - fruitily hopped, and with a big bitter finish. The alcohol is slightly noticeable on the finish.

A brilliant beer. Appears black and tan, like many another stout. The nose is fantastic, raspberry cremola foam mixed with treacle toffee. The palate has a lovely creamy character, plus a little bit of raspberry. A very well balanced finish rounds it all off nicely.
beer_name: Fallen / BrewDog Big Raspberry Dog Chew

review_blob: Bottle from The Good Spirits Co Wine & Beer. Slightly cloudy amber with a short lived white frothy head. Nose is initially kinda old fashioned - a little bit dusty, malty - before the fruity hop notes come through. There is also that sweet malty smell you get from strong Belgian styled beers. Palate is rich and boozy, with fruity sweetness, a solid bitter core, and some sort of spice in at the back. A very decent IPA, but it doesnt quite reach Imperial levels of flavour intensity in my opinion. Also, oats in an IPA? What the heck??

tasted at Dark Lord Sunday (20th Sept 2015).

In my opinion, this is too hoppy to be called a Pilsner. 

A delicious, light, blonde beer with a strong hoppy note through it.

500ml bottle from the Good Spirits Co Wine & Beer. Clear, golden, with a sparkle and a very short lived mousse. Very clean, cider apples, fresh fruit, and a touch of hay. Palate is medium sweet and juicy, with a light fizz. The finish is sharp & refreshing.
beer_name: Dragon Orchard Harry Taylors Thrown Hat Medium Cider

review_blob: 330ml bottle from the Good Spirits Co Wine & Beer. A cloudy amber with a big white frothy head. Nose is tart (preserved lemons, grapefruit pith). Palate is refeshing, tart, yellow fruits, ripe, juicy. Also kinda creamy (almost like coconut). Finish is a wee bit sticky, not so refreshing. Very good bitterness throughout. Good, but not great.
Can. Delicious aroma of milk chocolate. Palate is creamy, smooth, chocolate, but with some contrasting bitter notes. It gets more chocolatey as it goes down.
330ml bottle from Oddbins Mitchell St. Nose is hoppy & a bit gristy. Palate is citrus (lemon) & tropical. Texture is quite creamy (the oats?). Exxellent bitter-citrus finish

330ml can from the Good Spirits Co Wine & Beer. Very citrus (mandarin?) and slightly sweet, with creamy carbonation. The bitterness is very well balanced against the sweet notes, and the finish gets more bitter still. Good stuff.

12oz can from the Good Spirits Co Wine & Beer. Hazy gold with a white frothy head. Very interesting nose - citric & resinous hops, plus some elusive aroma which might be a womans perfume (but Ive really no idea which one). Palate is superbly bitter, rather light & fresh for the ABV, fruity and slightly sweet on the finish. Very enjoyable, but it really hides its alcoholic content.

Bottle from the Good Spirits Co Wine & Beer. Pours a beautiful red-amber with a frothy head. Nose is a bit too boozy, but with rich sweet malt. Palate is rich, sweet, creamy, with caramel malt. A long powerful finish.
From a shared can. Hazy gold, with a fast fading head. Bitter hops plus a raw grain aroma, then a bit of citrus. Light body, citrus, slightly floral hops. Very refreshing finish.

330ml can from the Good Spirits Wine & Beer, Glasgow. Pours a slightly hazy amber with a sudsy head which quickly falls to lacing. Aroma is straightforward bitter, not too big, not fruity. Palate is middle weight, bitter, a wee bit fruity, with some sweet caramel malt. Refreshingly bitter finish. Very good, but not what Id call new world style.
